TITLE: Glass act: Scientists reveal secrets of frog transparency
SUMMARY: Using light and ultrasound imaging technology, researchers discovered the secret: While asleep, the frogs concentrate, or “hide,” nearly 90% of their red blood cells in their livers

TITLE: Alzheimer's researchers study genes in Puerto Rican and Latino families
SUMMARY: They have found that in Puerto Rico, people have a higher propensity for the disease, and part of the reason could be a genetic variant they have uncovered

TITLE: EPA issues new rule to strengthen water protections in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Under the new definition of "waters of the United States," more wetlands, lakes and rivers will qualify as federally protected

TITLE: The year in space: Why 2022 was a pivotal year for exploration and discovery
SUMMARY: This year brought space fans images from the world’s most powerful space telescope, the debut launch of NASA’s moon rocket and a test to redirect an asteroid

TITLE: What is the XBB.1.5 subvariant? CDC reports a new strain of omicron taking over in the U.S.
SUMMARY: About 40% of confirmed U.S. Covid cases are caused by the XBB.1.5 strain, up from 20% a week ago

TITLE: 2022 was the year of drought
SUMMARY: Lakes and rivers in several countries shrank to extreme lows, and dry conditions threatened crops and fueled destructive wildfires across the globe

TITLE: Atmospheric river expected to trigger 'bomb cyclone' and more flooding in California
SUMMARY: Flood watches were in effect for 12 million people in the northern part of the state, including areas still recovering from recent storms and mudslides

TITLE: Walter Cunningham, last surviving Apollo 7 astronaut, dies at 90
SUMMARY: Cunningham's family said he died "after a full and complete life." He was one of three astronauts aboard the 1968 Apollo 7 mission

TITLE: Mexico's Mayan Train critically threatens ancient, pristine areas, scientists warn
SUMMARY: The railway and its hasty construction will endanger wilderness and ancient cave systems beneath the jungle floor, say droves of environmental experts and scientists

TITLE: U.S. greenhouse emissions show signs of slowing — but not quickly enough
SUMMARY: The Rhodium Group's analysis suggests the U.S. is off track to reach fast-approaching climate goals in 2025 and 2030

TITLE: Extreme weather caused $165 billion in damage last year, NOAA says
SUMMARY: It was the third-costliest year on record, highlighting the enormous economic and societal toll of extreme events that are expected to intensify because of climate change

TITLE: U.K. space industry mulls setback after satellite launch fails
SUMMARY: U.S.-based Virgin Orbit attempted its first international launch late Monday, using a modified jumbo jet to carry one if its rockets from Cornwall, England, over the Atlantic

TITLE: James Webb Telescope finds its first exoplanet
SUMMARY: The planet is almost the same size as Earth, according to a research team led by astronomers at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

TITLE: Surging rivers highlight a big dam problem for California
SUMMARY: Much of the infrastructure to help alleviate California’s too-wet/too-dry cycles — its extensive reservoir system — was designed long before it was recognized that climate change could intensify droughts and storms

TITLE: Exxon Mobil accurately predicted warming since 1970s, study finds
SUMMARY: The study in the journal Science looked at Exxon-funded research that used more than a dozen different computer models that forecast the coming warming with precision equal to or better that of than government and academic scientists

TITLE: NASA and NOAA find 2022 was one of the hottest years on record
SUMMARY: Though the two agencies differed slightly in their rankings, both analyses painted the same broad and alarming picture of persistent warming amid Earth’s changing climate

TITLE: More men diagnosed with advanced prostate cancer as PSA screening declines
SUMMARY: After two decades of decline, cases of prostate cancer rose by 3% per year from 2014 to 2019, a new report from the American Cancer Society has found

TITLE: Norway archaeologists find 'world's oldest runestone'
SUMMARY: The flat, square block of brownish sandstone has carved scribbles, which may be the earliest example of words recorded in writing in Scandinavia
